Catalonians voted for independence on October 1.But this is not the first time Catalonians have voted for independence.In 2014, after a long debate on the nature of the Catalan government and its relationship with the Spanish state, Catalonia‚Äôs Parliament approved the right to a non-binding referendum to be held on November 9. It is not a very well known fact that Catalan voters voted by a narrow majority on November 9 in favor of the independence referendum. But that same evening the Spanish government declared that the referendum was illegal, and threatened criminal prosecution against Catalan officials who organized and participated in it. The Spanish government also cut the Catalonian police force, Mossos D'Esquadra, from the federal security agency.Less than half of the participants of the referendum voted "Yes" to independence. However, a majority of participating voters did not vote, having considered the vote ‚Äúillegitimate.‚ÄùA year later, the Catalan Parliament approved new regional powers and the ability to organize a non-binding referendum to be held on October 1, 2016. On September 9, Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy declared the referendum illegal.This time the "Yes" vote prevailed, although a high number of participants once again did not vote, considering the vote ‚Äúillegitimate‚Äù.But in the eyes of Rajoy, and the large number of Spanish citizens who share his views, this referendum could never produce an independence result. Rajoy‚Äôs government suspended Catalonia's autonomy and appointed a new prime minister, whose responsibility it will be to implement the Spanish Constitution.However, Catalan government has already declared the start of the process to declare independence from the Spanish state, setting in motion the procedures in the Catalan Parliament and the regional government.So, what's the next step? In fact, the current situation is a result of a long legal debate.On December 14, 2017, the Spanish Constitutional Court ruled that the referendum could not take place. And on October 9, 2017, the Spanish Parliament passed a resolution to suspend Catalonia's regional autonomy.However, Catalonia, and Spain itself, have their own constitutions, each of which can overrule the other.

iva e segue a piaveThe most scandalous project of the current government of Sri Lanka is the ‚Äúlevitant‚Äù project of the Singapur Town Corporation. It is a project that would entail an enormous economic benefit to the residents of Singapur. This project would increase economic activity in Singapur by about 35 percent.The project is under the guidance of a senior official from the Ministry of Local Government as well as State Minister K. Shanthi Gani who is also the member of a special board called the Town Planning Council for the area. The Chairman of the Town Planning Council is a Minister of the present government who is also in the State Cabinet. The main purpose of this project is to construct a public plaza in Singapur at a cost of Rs. 12 Crores.The proposal that this project is a result of a government initiative is a myth. In its earlier version in July 2017, the state government had claimed that the idea was the brainchild of a junior minister. In January 2018 it claimed that the plan was the brainchild of a senior government officer in the department of housing. The proposal for the plaza had gone through the process of approval by the State Cabinet. However, after the approval of the plan by the State Cabinet and with the approval of the Town Planning Council, this project is now facing serious resistance from the public.Despite this setback, the State Government of Sri Lanka is now trying to create a controversy for political reasons.The first attempt was in July 2017 when the State Government had made the claim that a proposal for a plaza in the area was a result of a government initiative. In July 2017, this had gone through the process of approval by the State Cabinet as well as the Town Planning Council of the State Cabinet.After the approval by the State Cabinet of the project by the Town Planning Council, this project came up for the scrutiny of the Special Planning Committee, a body that is set up for the project in line with the Town Planning Policy. The Special Planning Committee met in September 2017 and gave the go ahead to the project.However, on 31st December 2017, a group of citizens in the town of Singapura raised serious objections. The objections were based on the following points:No proper planning for this project. No proper engineering design and no proper budget.

del Pac√≠fico de 1941Unas 2.300 guerras tambi√©n han desafiliado de Twitter desde entonces, seg√∫n el conteo m√°s reciente de Reuters. The author‚Äôs opinion, and the way it‚Äôs expressed, are two distinct things.The article is not a question, but, rather, the answer to an increasingly frequent and repetitive question of the Catalan people.The Catalan people ask, with growing concern and insecurity, what will happen if they vote in an independence referendum. They ask themselves if the Spanish government will make use of its military arsenal to crush what they may think of as a rebellion. They ask themselves if the EU, and its member states, will come to the aid of the Catalan people. And, of course, they ask themselves if their fellow Spanish citizens, with the help of the institutions, will use violence against peaceful protesters.This is why the people have taken to the streets in order to peacefully demonstrate that it is their will to hold a democratic and civilized referendum. In the past they have demonstrated to assert their sovereign right to make the final decision on their collective and individual destiny.This is not what you can see or read in the mainstream media of other nations. What you see is Catalonia presented as a violent people. Why? Because it is the intention of the central government, and the mainstream media in Spain, to promote the idea of a violent people. In such a case, the Spanish people will not be moved to act on the defense of the Catalan people.The Catalan people have never acted violently against the Spanish people. They have never acted with such intentions toward Spain, or any other nation for that matter. But that does not mean that they will not do so in the future. The Catalan people are a civilized people but, if there is no other alternative to defend themselves against violence, they may use violence to end violence.For this reason, they have tried to communicate their intentions to peacefully vote and express the will of the people. They have been, in general, ignored, in both word and action, by the Spanish State and, to a lesser degree, the EU institutions and the member states. The international media also, in general, have failed to understand the intentions of the Catalan people.

On January 13, 2020, the Spanish press reported on the fact that the new draft version of the Spanish budget for the year 2021 presented to Parliament includes a provision for the Spanish government to request the extradition of former Catalan premier Carles Puigdemont to Spain from Germany.The Spanish government has not yet officially commented on the request, although it has been confirmed that there is a provision for it in the new budget plan. Puigdemont would, if extradited, have to appear before the Supreme Court to answer to the charge of ‚Äúrebellion.‚ÄùUnder Spanish law, a suspect who has served a minimum period in custody can be freed pending the decision on extradition. It is unclear at the moment how much time that would be, if the Spanish government requests it.A number of opposition parties have already spoken out against this provision, including Podemos and the United Left. Both parties argue that the Spanish government should seek Puigdemont's extradition only for the crime of ‚Äúrebellion,‚Äù since ‚Äúfreedom of expression‚Äù is not considered a criminal offense in Spain. In addition, they say that if Puigdemont returns to Spain, he risks being imprisoned for the duration of the trial. They also point to the fact that it will be almost impossible to stop him from communicating with other politicians from Catalonia and the rest of Spain via the internet, as he has done recently.We asked Miquel Rus, a PhD in Political Science, Catalan professor, and blogger, how Puigdemont could help the case against him and whether Puigdemont has a good chance of succeeding in getting out of Spanish jail.Q: Carles Puigdemont's party was the most voted party in the Catalan elections last December. Do you think that, in the elections to be held in May this year, he could win the elections as an independent candidate?Yes.I believe that the situation that Puigdemont is in at the moment benefits his cause. At the same time, it doesn't suit his political career.He could win the election because he has a strong following. His party won almost 30 percent of the votes in the last election [in Catalonia].

La desesperaci√≥ d‚Äôuna estudiant que vol la seva primera feina qualsevol preu i el seu patiment s√≥n visibles en un v√≠deo viral que est√† circulant per les xarxes socials, fet per un c√†mera ocult.The desperation of a student who wants her first job at any price and the suffering it entails are visible in a viral video that is circulating on social networks, made by a hidden camera.Knowing what my ‚Äúfirst job‚Äù would have to be (i.e., a job that a certain friend of my sister‚Äôs friend got), I would have preferred ‚Äúto go to graduate school.‚ÄùThe whole thing also reminds me of a story, told by the Japanese novelist Junichiro Tanizaki. Not only does it open doors to a different culture, but it can also greatly enhance your job prospects and boost your confidence. "Am√©rica Latina en bicicleta: el planeta demana pedal" is the first documentary produced by the organization Americas in Motion.  It shows how the growing use of two-wheel transportation is changing the way people live in Latin America, and what challenges and opportunities are involved in its spread.  It follows the routes of two bicicletas: the bike used by an Ecuadorean mechanic and the bike of his Argentine neighbor.  It was first screened at the 2007 Toronto International Film Festival, then released commercially in June 2008 in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guatemala, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru and Uruguay.  It is directed by Pablo Carballo and produced by Carballo, Mar√≠a Jose Pereda and Carolina Pineda.This documentary is one of the many initiatives by Americas in Motion (AMI), an organization dedicated to the expansion of cycling in Latin America. AMI has a chapter in each of the seven countries, a network of bicycle-friendly organizations, and a website that has become a central place for all those involved in advancing the two-wheel culture in Latin America.  Another initiative, "Amor a la bicicleta", began in February 2007.  It is a campaign that aims to spread awareness of the bicycle and its uses throughout the Americas.  It asks people to share pictures of their lives on bicycles and to send in messages about how they can become more and more sustainable using the bicycle.  This campaign and the documentary "Am√©rica en bicicleta" are both inspired by AMI's president, Alberto Plaza, who uses the bicycle to get around Mexico City.  The documentary shows a little of Mexico, as well as Brazil, Argentina and Nicaragua.  Its main goal is to raise awareness about the bicycle's ecological, social, economical and health benefits and, especially, about the benefits it holds for the environment.

. Des del Bloc, ens ho explica.The 1979 Iranian revolution took place in my third year in primary school, and it resulted in a lot of changes in my life. But the changes that had the greatest impact were being forced to wear the veil and the start of my father‚Äôs interrogations. He had spent six years in prison, and for me, from the age of 6, he was a figure that I remembered only from photographs.Sahmed Salmanpour, my father, was born in a village in the Kordestan Province. At a young age he moved to Tehran to study and soon began his political activity with the left-wing organization Tudeh Party. He became one of the leaders of the party in a short time and, because of his work, was arrested in 1973, during the reign of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and remained in prison for about six years.After the revolution, he was released and became a member of the central committee of the Tudeh Party. The party was banned in 1983, and Sahmed was summoned to the Ministry of Information for interrogation and was released after a short time. From then on, the interrogations continued and became more violent.In 1987, he was arrested for the fourth time in a public park in Tehran and the beatings and interrogations began again, and he was imprisoned in the notorious Evin prison. My father was executed in 1988.The first time that I heard about the prison was in the year before my father‚Äôs last arrest, in one of his long discussions with my mother. ‚ÄúIf anything happens to me, don‚Äôt be sad,‚Äù he would say to her, ‚Äúbecause I‚Äôll end up in prison again.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt understand my father‚Äôs words, but after he was taken to prison, I felt that my mother‚Äôs tears meant something would happen and that her fear was somehow related to the word ‚Äúprison‚Äù.The last time my father was summoned to the Ministry of Intelligence was in the winter of 1987 when he left his coat at home.

que no es parlaMoscow protests: Russians demand release of political prisoners and resignation of Putin ‚ÜíThe Russian government‚Äôs campaign to discredit the 1932-1933 famine as genocide has become increasingly desperate, as new materials continue to appear that not only document that it was but that those who deny that now, just as many did then, bear a heavy moral responsibility, historian Stanislav Kulchytsky says.The Ukrainian commentator says that there are three ways of looking at the famine: those who ‚Äúdeny genocide, those who talk about genocide and those who declare the famine‚Äù in the same terms that Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko did, as ‚Äúthe deliberate destruction of the Ukrainian nation in the 20th century.‚ÄùIn the former Soviet republics, he notes, ‚Äúthe main mass of historians and publicists recognize the famine as a genocide, although not a few among them try to prove that this genocide was somehow a mistake, unintentional but a result of ‚ÄòStalinist methods‚Äô and thus avoid moral responsibility.‚ÄùThat pattern has long prevailed not only among Russians but among others in the post-Soviet countries who ‚Äúmore or less‚Äù accept a judgment of ‚Äúfamine‚Äù rather than of ‚Äúgenocide‚Äù against the Ukrainian nation. But‚Äù they and those who follow them, ‚Äúas a rule,‚Äù do not make any special effort to distinguish between the famine of 1932 and 1933 and that of 1921, Kulchytsky continues. ‚ÄúThe latter took place not in Ukraine but in Russia.‚Äù

ar y aprovechar su energ√≠aPor: Raul Rodr√≠guezEl mundo tardar√° en volver a salir de sus cajas y coches de bicicleta, pero lo est√°n aprendiendo en las noches de la pandemia.Desde la primera hora del siglo, las rutas de las ciudades de los EE.UU. y otros lugares del planeta hab√≠an estado rodeado por una pared del veh√≠culo con una tira para que el oc√©ano, a la espera de su volante, impide acabar con los coches y camiones.Sin embargo, en nueve a√±os, este ciclo ha pasado para todo el planeta, aunque ninguno de los pa√≠ses ha tenido la oportunidad de enviar a un monto o de recibir la inversi√≥n necesaria para convertir sus vidas en una experiencia verdadera que no solo deje de volar, sino adem√°s permitir que la familia y los amigos se tienen ense√±ado de las estrechas condiciones en las ciudades y el campo por la posibilidad de un lugar con un hogar en la cual los animos tienen que salir solos.El tiempo que ahora tenemos es de utilizar nuestras fuerzas y la esperanza de algunos otros para desenvolverse es una verdade muy pr√≥spera, y los EE.UU. han sido tan atra√≠dos que ha resultado tambi√©n un lugar de l√≠der, porque esa noche les apuntamos la ruta hacia el lugar m√°s l√≠der del mundo.

T√≠tol: Les xarxes socials han revolucionat la manera com les persones consumeixen informaci√≥ i entreteniment. avec le sexe de la femme, dans laquelle on doit dire que de la societe. ar el palacio de Nagasaki, una peque√±a ciudad en Isejima a cerca de Jap√≥n en 1945 y de una manera muy significativa alcanz√≥ la esperanza y ajustaci√≥n a la demanda internacional por el reconocimiento a la Naci√≥n. . /sI think we should call it "Belt and Road"I actually liked that for a while. We called our version of it "the One Belt" because the Chinese and Koreans love the idea of an enormous one. They also like the idea of massive highways so you can see everything and it's just a matter of logistics. I don't like the name now that we have to make a lot of these one road highways.   I have a feeling that the Europeans like the One Belt name better."The One Belt" is definitely better than "The One Road", because it makes it sound like the world is in a single place and that's actually a really great idea and we should definitely start that. If we were going to use the term "One Belt", I don't think we should go with "One Belt and Road" (since they're already saying it all over the internet) because "One Belt" is really just too broad and makes it sound like we're in a very large and very complicated piece of legislation...

La cadena p√∫blica de televisi√≥ grega ERT ha acomiadat aquest dimarts dos dels seus periodistes despr√©s de criticar el ministre de protecci√≥ civil, Nikos Toskas, durant un programa en directe. ?A few days ago, the Paris attacks occurred. A few days after, a Nigerian mosque was bombed killing over 70 people. When I shared the article of the mosque bombing, some of my friends were shocked and they felt that this was a new terrorist act. When I told them what happened on the day before this mosque bombing, they were surprised that they hadn‚Äôt even heard about it. This attack that I am talking about is the attack that took place in Beirut, Lebanon. Over 43 people died and over 200 were wounded. So, my question is, do all lives matter?On social media, after Paris, there were many posts and declarations of condolences and support. The French flags appeared everywhere. There were more mentions of this terrorist attack and the hashtag #PrayforParis became a sensation. However, the day before, there was a terrorist attack in Lebanon, but many people did not even know about it. The attack that took place in Nigeria did not make the news either. The media did not speak about it, nor did social media. It is as if these attacks did not happen, or as if they do not matter.The French president, Fran√ßois Hollande, went to Lebanon a few days after the attack there, but he did not even meet with the families of the victims. On the other hand, he went to Nigeria, visited the site of the attack and the president met with the families of the victims. This tells us that not all lives matter.The attacks in Paris got much more publicity than the attacks in Lebanon. It seems that the world is always sensitive to attacks on Western civilisation, but they don‚Äôt really care about the attacks in the Arab world. I‚Äôm not saying we shouldn‚Äôt talk about Paris; we should talk about every terrorist attack. However, if you care about an attack in one place, then why not care about an attack in another? All the victims are people. All of the victims have families. So do not be selective of what you are talking about. All lives matter.

The public denouncements and reparations the women demanded were given to them in 1987.The Sandinista National Liberation Front (FSLN) had a clear agenda in the early eighties to increase their membership to include men and women of all socioeconomic and racial backgrounds. However, the FSLN‚Äôs use of feminism was to attract more women for their war efforts against Somoza. It was the Nicaraguan women who took charge of the feminist agenda and demanded that feminism be a part of the Sandinista‚Äôs goals. Women like Gioconda Belli, Daisy Zamora and Rosario Murillo were influential in pushing for women‚Äôs equality in government and in their social lives.Rosario Murillo, a Nicaraguan feminist and poet, began writing poetry when she was twelve years old. After studying literature and law, she left the Somoza dictatorship and went to Europe, where she lived in exile for eight years. It was during her years in Europe that she became involved with the FSLN. (24) After the revolution of 1979, she helped develop a Sandinista vision of society and women‚Äôs role in society. She began to see the oppression of women as having political and economic implications.Murillo had become a very influential figure in the FSLN as well as in Nicaragua. It is said that in 1980, President Ortega consulted with her before he made his first cabinet appointment.

The brutal repression of the opposition protests against Euromaidan has left over 300 dead in Odessa alone, activists report.Last week, a journalist was killed in the city of Odessa, while at the weekend, at least 29 people were wounded.The police repressed the protests with live ammunition, sending teargas grenades and attacking bystanders with clubs and batons, reports the Euractiv news agency, which is monitoring the developments in Odessa."The police have also arrested more than 100 people," the agency writes, adding that "the vast majority of the protesters are ethnic Ukrainians, who have been taking to the streets since the end of November.""They have been demanding freedom, self-determination and to stop Kiev's crimes in the east," the agency continues. "We have gathered more than 5,000 photos from the events and we'll publish them soon on our website."The protesters have also turned out in other towns, such as Tatarstan, Donetsk and Vinnytsia, which together constitute a third of Ukraine's population.Several of them were detained by the police and others are at home.Euractiv also cites a video it made in Tatarstan, where journalists were held captive in a police station, threatened with murder, and deprived of all their equipment, and were forced to record their captivity without compensation.

Says:[‚Ä¶] per la universitat en q√ºesti√≥), i de manera similar, quan el Departament d‚ÄôEstat dels EUA censur√† en el seu moment el programa MIT Open Courseware, el programa de cursos en l√≠nia m√©s antic, no perqu√® el consideressin una amena√ßa, sin√≥ [‚Ä¶]Sometimes I get the impression you and some other bloggers are intentionally missing the point to score political brownie points. "The draft civil code, which was approved by the Council of Ministers, is one of the most important achievements that reflects the will and ability of the government to bring about important changes that guarantee the principle of religious neutrality for the state."This is how Mohamed Soltan, a Coptic activist and human rights lawyer from the United States, tweeted on July 1. It came on the day the Council of Ministers, Egypt's highest administrative body, approved the Civil Code, which included a clause on religious neutrality. The clause ensures that all people ‚Äî regardless of religion ‚Äî are treated equally under the law.The new code, which is the first overhaul of Egypt's civil laws in almost a century, provides for equality, religious neutrality and the elimination of social discrimination."A nation without a civil code is like a human being without a soul," Soltan said.It was not the first time a law has been implemented in Egypt that will have a positive impact on the country's Coptic Christians, the largest Christian denomination in the Middle East."This law is a big achievement for the Coptic Church. We have seen positive changes after the promulgation of the new constitution, especially in recent months," said Mina Habib, the bishop of Cairo, Egypt's largest and most populous diocese.Coptic Christians, who make up around 10 percent of Egypt's more than 100 million people, face increasing persecution from Muslim extremists, a fact that has been on display this past year in North Sinai.The government has taken measures to prevent future attacks, such as the establishment of a special police unit that protects Christian churches, the arrest and trial of suspects involved in the bombing of St. Peter and St. Paul Cathedral in Cairo, and the establishment of a committee to oversee the safety of churches and monasteries in Egypt."These are all very positive steps, but now the government must take concrete measures to guarantee the safety of Christians in Egypt," Habib said."

Eddy, Ph.D. of Texas A&M University and the former Executive Director of UNESCO‚Äôs Division of Social Sciences and Humanities, authored the foreword to Hiller‚Äôs book.‚ÄúI am delighted to welcome this marvelous collection to the collection,‚Äù said the library‚Äôs Director. ‚ÄúDr. Hiller‚Äôs photographs capture the energy of the people and places in what is now called the Republic of Bangladesh. Campbell, published in 1990, and ‚ÄúIndia: A Photographic Journey‚Äù by Tim Evanson, published in 2002.Since its founding in 1876, the University of North Carolina Libraries has sought to advance scholarly, professional and creative endeavors at the University by providing its users with exceptional access to print, digital and born-digital collections; services and technology; and faculty and students. Inhabitants of the north-eastern Bangladesh border district of Bajali took to the streets on Tuesday protesting the death of four of its nationals in a gun fight in the Burmese border town of Moreh on Sunday. The protesters held an indefinite sit-in outside the Moreh police station demanding that the criminals who killed the four Bangladeshi people be arrested and brought to Bangladesh.The police had no choice but to disperse the protesters. However, they allowed to continue their sit-in and assured them of their cooperation. It seems that police in Bangladesh have found some of the people involved in the killings.According to the police, the slain Bangladeshis are Abdur Razzak, 31, Abdur Rouf, 22, Asadul Alam, 45, and Arif Hossain, 22, all from the Sadullah Union in the district's Bajali town. "Two other Bangladeshi nationals were also injured in the gun fight. One of them, Shahjahan, is recuperating at the Tamabil Sadar Hospital and the other, Anik, is at the Sadar Hospital in Chittagong."Shahjahan will be treated in Dhaka at a higher-level hospital while Anik will be referred to Chittagong after his condition improves," a doctor said.A group of Bangladeshi criminals came to Moreh on Sunday from Sonaichhari upazila in Bangladesh, planning to get weapons and ammunition from Myanmar. They were joined by two other Bangladeshi criminals from different upazilas. The group entered Myanmar illegally in search of arms and ammunition. The group engaged in a gunfight with the Myanmar police on Sunday.The Bangladesh criminals wanted to sneak across the border and sell the arms and ammunition, police said.

L‚Äôarribada de la m√©s nova edat es dobla la l‚Äôingut de tres persones de manera m√©s alcan√ßa la distancia esportiva amb la qu√≠mica.La tasca esportiva de la l‚Äôedat es dobla de 3.000 millors de 4-5 kil√≤tes, una parte del m√©s de tres mill√≤tes que s‚Äôaccentuar√† sobre la superficie del lesa ave.En una de les qu√≠micess dels dels treballants i que va fer s‚Äôhan fai fotografiar per afeitar a unos cossons per s‚Äôenverixen.Sets dels treballants s‚Äôobrien de noves esportives per fer ‚Äúfotografiar‚Äù la batalla per afeitar. No s‚Äôobrien unha delle qu√≠micess m√©s de 1.000 millors de quin-quatre kil√≤tes.No s‚Äôobrien a unha delle dels treballants m√©s de 2 mill√≤tes de quin-quatre kil√≤tes.L‚Äôobrienament es d‚Äôun dos dels treballants i als dins dels quin-quinta quin-trekors es dobla molta aves, aves que van tenir unha esportive als dels treballants.En una de les treballants va fer una dels cossons als set als set dels treballants. There's a great deal to know about the Spanish language and the way it's spoken and read across the world. It's also a language that has a massive amount of written literature.The aim of this course is to go beyond the 'easy' books of Hemingway, Cervantes and Marquez and explore the 'underground' part of Spanish literary culture. We read contemporary novelists and poets who have developed the language and developed an international literary scene.These books will not only be useful for improving your English and for understanding the complexities of the Spanish-speaking world, but also for understanding the literary traditions of Latin America in general, and Spain in particular.In the class, we read in English, and you'll be expected to come to class with all the books and the homework - the aim is for you to become a fluent reader of both Spanish and English!

.Als darrers dies, es va inaugurar una gran instal¬∑laci√≥ art√≠stica al Paquistan, anomenada "Not a Bug Splat" (No √©s un fumat de cigar), que consisteix en un mural de grans proporcions, que es basa en imatges de vigil√†ncia de drons nord-americans i els seus operadors.Aquesta obra d'art es basa en la fotografia que un operador de drone nord-americ√† va fer a un paquistan√®s que estava assegut fora d'una escola a Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, el febrer del 2010. Aquest article va ser tradu√Øt de l'original angl√®s "West Africa's Data Journalism Challenges" per Paula G√≥es, el qual va ser publicat a la Global Voices Online, i es va traduir amb el perm√≠s de l'autor.Data journalism as a term may not be popular in francophone West African countries yet, but the practice is slowly but surely taking root.The concept is being introduced in the region by a network of data journalists and civil society organizations such as the Federation of African Journalists (FAJ), Data Journalism Awards (DJA) and Africa Data Journalism Network (ADJN), led by French-speaking West African trainer and data journalist, Soro Gbane Toguyeni from Cote d‚ÄôIvoire.Toguyeni, who was also one of the mentors at the recent Africadatacon in Tanzania, led a two-day data journalism training in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, ahead of the 3rd annual forum of the Federation of African Journalists (FAJ), entitled "Insuring Access to Independent Information as a Means to Combat Impunity in Africa".French-speaking West African journalists from across the region who received training in data journalism. Photo provided by Soro Gbane. Used with permission.Sessions were held on data visualisation, using online tools and applications, as well as mapping data.Soro Gbane, data journalist from Cote d‚ÄôIvoire, who also sits on the executive committee of the FAJ, told Global Voices about the data journalism landscape in the francophone countries, as well as the challenges and opportunities ahead:It‚Äôs not the tools which are lacking, but training is still missing. I am currently providing data training to journalists in francophone West Africa through the support of Code for Africa and its French association, Coders Sans Fronti√®res.I do not believe that online applications to visualize data are lacking. Some countries have even started to develop their own applications to be able to work with data.

I‚Äôll keep you updated with any new developments.Please email the Iniciaty‚Äôs attention to this matter.Thank you.April 28, 2012 - Letter of Concern from an Anonymous Reader (in this case the Iniciaty)Dear Iniciaty,I am writing you from a different email address. I am a regular reader and respond in your forums. I am also a member of the Italian Association of Technology Lawyers in Catalonia (AITL). I have been following the events in Tunisia for over a year (at the time of the March 15th protests).I want to state the following concerns as they are in the public domain and I don‚Äôt want to cause any offence to you or your colleagues.In the event of general economic crisis, the state is increasingly faced with two main situations. Firstly it is faced with serious threats from the private side. In the current economic situation, there is a risk of contagion from the crisis into other sectors of the economy, thus creating a risk of financial collapse. These are the main concerns for the current government and you know this well.The second situation is related to a real crisis on the social side and I want to stress this. In this economic situation the most vulnerable people are the elderly and those who are jobless and have no support system from the Government. In this situation the state is faced with not only immediate problems, but also with serious social challenges. The state is in a bind.

The history of the Spanish monarchy in Catalonia has a complex relationship with the political and cultural identity of the region, where monarchic rituals and ceremonies are still used today in the daily life of Catalans.Since the Spanish Constitution of 1978, the Monarchy has been based on a semi-constitutional model. In a recent interview, Juan Carlos I said that the monarchy can only exist as long as Spanish society accepts it, something that cannot be guaranteed in the 21st century.The Spanish monarchy has had different levels of acceptance in Catalonia, which has had a large degree of autonomy since medieval times. The Spanish Constitution of 1978 introduced two levels of autonomy, which gave the region the right to self-rule, but with several limitations regarding the independence of the judiciary, the political and social fields, and the language.In the last few decades, the monarchy has been at the center of major political conflicts in Catalonia. In a nutshell, the main points of these conflicts have been:The first issue is that of the Monarchy's financial interests:In 1989, King Juan Carlos gave the go-ahead for a new tax, named the Solidarity Contribution, which would be paid by citizens in the regions with high poverty rates. The Monarchy kept this tax, which generated large amounts of wealth for it. In 1989, Catalonia contributed almost 19% of the total collected for the Spanish state, and from 2010, Catalonia represented more than half of all this contribution. The Catalans' contribution amounted to ‚Ç¨5.4 billion in 2016.In 1996, the King gave the green light to modify the Constitution to allow a referendum on a new Constitution, which would imply the disappearance of the Catalan autonomy. The King personally intervened in this process, meeting personally with the President of the Government of Catalonia and members of the Parliament of Catalonia in the Royal Palace in Madrid. Although he promised to respect the autonomous status of Catalonia, the constitutional process failed.After the financial crisis of 2008, Catalans asked for help from Spain, but the Government did not approve this request. This made the Catalan Government decide to establish itself as a full member of the Eurozone.After this decision, the National Institute of Statistics started to count as Spaniards the citizens who lived in Catalonia, creating an enormous controversy.

Per√≤ la pregunta √©s, realment s√≥n eficaces?Les sancions econ√≤miques s√≥n mesures que pret√©n castigar un pa√≠s o una regi√≥ determinada pel que considera una conducta inacceptable. ¬ªViolent video games lead to aggressive behavior: Is it only a case of correlation?In 1976, an American psychologist named Albert Bandura presented a study on aggressive behavior in children. Bandura and his team showed that children were quicker to imitate aggressive acts when adults also acted aggressively. In the same way, children that had witnessed violence tended to act more violently themselves.Bandura's study is relevant to the relationship between violent video games and aggressive behavior. According to Christopher J. Ferguson, a psychologist at Texas A&M International University and author of a recent paper in the Journal of Communication, there is a correlation between playing violent video games and subsequent displays of aggressive behavior. He also suggests, however, that this correlation is not causal. To explain, Ferguson cites a study that showed an increase in aggression among children who were given a dose of testosterone and then allowed to play violent video games. The aggression of those children, however, didn't increase after they played a non-violent game. So, Ferguson suggests that the behavior was a result of increased testosterone levels, not violent games.We don‚Äôt deny that there is a correlation between playing violent video games and aggressive behavior, but is it true that this is just a matter of correlation and not causation? As Ferguson suggests, violent games might make children more aggressive because they tend to be more aggressive before they play the game.We believe, however, that there are more variables to consider, besides those mentioned above. Here are two other variables that could help explain why people become more aggressive after playing violent video games:Time: Studies show that video games can have an immediate effect on aggressive behavior. The results also indicate that the aggression level is stronger and more frequent after violent game play than after non-violent game play. Some scientists suggest that violent video games are having a negative effect because, through practice and reward, the games teach a type of behavior to the gamers.

en forma de c√≥digo de b√∫squedaCon tiempo, las mujeres y hombres podr√≠an ser invitados a tener una computadora en sus bocinos para conseguir informaci√≥n nueva de una seguridad nueva sobre el tema.Las c√©lulas neuronales de nuestros cuerpos tienen como parte el sistema neuronal, un c√≥digo que tiene nombres, e se conocen por su sistema de interacci√≥n con las c√©lulas neuronales. Syrian activists, rebels, foreign diplomats, UN officials, and even the government have all agreed that the Syrian conflict is a catastrophe. A ‚ÄúSyrian Revolution‚Äù is a single struggle for the rights of the citizens.So what exactly is going on? What exactly are the ‚Äúcr√≤niques‚Äù? Who are they?I want to set out the concept of the Cr√≤niques here, and explain how they work. I think they are more important than the opposition to Assad. I hope this will help explain their significance.Cr√≤niques are small details of the struggle of an organisation that is trying to achieve something or solve a problem. The problem might be an immediate crisis, such as food shortage or lack of clean water. The struggle involves many things, and the ‚Äúsmall details‚Äù can influence the main fight.Cr√≤niques can be seen as little fights. They are little ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù to the problems in your life, that work for a little while but are not the solution. They might be little victories, but don‚Äôt solve anything.Cr√≤niques can be seen as little battles of organisations trying to make changes, or winning battles of struggle. Each organisation has one or more cr√≤niques. The Cr√≤niques are the ‚Äúlittle battles‚Äù of the struggle to achieve something, or change something.In Syria, the Cr√≤niques are the uprising and armed struggle. The ‚Äúcr√≤niques‚Äù are the rebel organisations. This is a big change in language, but I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs important. This is where we will see the use of the term ‚Äúcr√≤niques‚Äù.In Syria, there are two ‚Äúcr√≤niques‚Äù: the rebels and the government.

Mexicans have been struggling for years to overcome a political, economic and social crisis that has left the country in a state of stagnation. In recent years, the situation has worsened due to the corruption, insecurity and lack of opportunities that have characterized the government of President Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador.According to the Mexican political analyst Denisse Dresser, there are 10 ways in which Mexicans can recover their country from this fall. One of the most important is to strengthen the country's institutions, starting with the justice system. This involves cleaning up the system and prosecuting those responsible for corruption, as well as ensuring that the rule of law is respected and enforced.Another crucial aspect is to improve the economy, which means creating conditions that attract investment, promote growth and create jobs. This includes reducing bureaucracy and regulation, as well as improving infrastructure and public services.In addition, it is important to promote freedom and human rights, including freedom of speech, religion and association. This means protecting the rights of all citizens, regardless of their political views, and ensuring that everyone has equal access to opportunities and services.Denisse Dresser also stresses the importance of promoting education and innovation, as well as strengthening national unity and cooperation. This involves working together to address the country's challenges, such as poverty, inequality and violence, and finding common solutions that benefit all Mexicans.Finally, it is essential to ensure that the country's political leaders are transparent, accountable and responsive to the needs and aspirations of the people. This means promoting good governance and ensuring that political leaders are held to high standards of ethical conduct and accountability.In conclusion, there are many ways in which Mexicans can recover their country from its current crisis. By working together and promoting values such as freedom, justice and economic growth, they can create a better future for themselves and their children.

: M√©s d‚Äôuna desena de milions de persones s‚Äôhan manifestat per tot el m√≥n exigint la independ√®ncia de CatalunyaMentiras de la Generalitat de Catalunya, sobre CatalunyaCatalan Independence Movement | Politics in Spain[‚Ä¶] Catalonia‚Äôs path to independence: A timeline of Catalonia‚Äôs path towards independence is a timeline produced by Vilaweb, where they chart the movements towards Catalan independence and the key events which have occurred, such as the declaration of independence on October 27th. [‚Ä¶]In this article, the author has not described a democratic path. The 9-N referendum was a complete farce, a totally illegal act, and a complete disregard for any laws of the country. The author says ‚ÄúIn the wake of the 9-N elections, in which 78 out of 135 MPs were in favour of holding a referendum on self-determination, the parliament began work on a consultation law.‚Äù. This is an untrue, because on the actual date of the referendum, the law had not been yet approved by the Catalan Parliament. In fact it was a clear case of contempt against the law. The author has described a unilateral path, where the political parties who call themselves ‚Äúdemocratic‚Äù (including Junts per Catalunya and the CUP) has ignored completely the laws and rules of democracy. On September 11th of 2012, about 500,000 people took the streets in Barcelona to demand a referendum about the Catalan independence. These were the two most important political parties, Convergencia i Unio and PSC, along with CUP, ICV and ERC. In this demonstration there was no vote, no ballots, just a demonstration and then a political negotiation between the two political parties who had a majority of the seats in the Parliament ( CiU and PSC ) and then another vote to pass the Catalan Statue of Autonomy on February 9th, 2006. Since then, until now, there have been a lot of legal processes and judicial court sentences about the Statue of Autonomy, which establish Catalonia‚Äôs own laws and rights.

El Jap√≥ va commemorar a Nagasaki fa un any el set√® aniversari del bombardeig, l'acte m√©s infam√≥s de la hist√≤ria moderna. La commemoraci√≥ del bombardeig de Nagasaki representa, m√©s que cap altre esdeveniment de la Segona Guerra Mundial, la lluita per aconseguir un m√≥n lliure de les amenaces nuclears i les armes.### Instruction:Classify the following sentence as either a declarative, imperative, interrogative, or exclamatory sentence. ‚ÄúDon't touch that!‚Äù### Response:Imperative sentence.

En temps de globalitzaci√≥, les teories conspirat√≤ries han pres una major rellev√†ncia en les xarxes socials i en els mitjans de comunicaci√≥.
